column1: Question
column2:
Score
zero (none), one (a litte), two (somewhat), three (a lot).

column1: Video
Workload is spread over the whole team (one team member is often Xtimes more productive than the others...but nevertheless, here is a track record that everyone is contributing a lot)
Number of commits
Number of commits: by different people
Issues reports: there are many
Issues are being closed
DOI badge: exists
Docs: doco generated, format not ugly
Docs: what: point descriptions of each class/function (in isolation)
column3: Each function has a docstring to it which explains what the function does

column1: Docs: how: for common use cases X,Y,Z mini-tutorials showing worked examples on how to do X,Y,Z
column3: Animated GIFs for every function in readme https://github.com/ojas1901/spendwise/blob/main/README.md

column1: Docs: why: docs tell a story, motivate the whole thing, deliver a punchline that makes you want to rush out and use the thing
Docs: short video, animated, hosted on your repo. That convinces people why they want to work on your code.
Use of version control tools
Use of style checkers
Use of code formatters.
Use of syntax checkers.
Use of code coverage:
column3: Codecov (code cov config file in repo)

column1: Other automated analysis tools
column3: Some linting is there (pylint config file in repo)

column1: Test cases exist
Test cases are routinely executed
The files CONTRIBUTING.md lists coding standards and lots of tips on how to extend the system without screwing things up
Issues are discussed before they are closed
Chat channel: exists
column3: We used notion as a chat and ideation channel. We also used whatsapp and zoom for communications whenever possible. https://www.notion.so/Project-3-SE-Fall-2023-Group-17-b04c0788365e4746b9344b4fb818b24d?pvs=4

column1: Test cases: a large proportion of the issues related to handling failing cases.
column3: Some bugs were fixed but they were not recognized using tests

column1: Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools: everyone can get to all tools and files
column3: Yes, no access control and open-source

column1: Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools (e.g. config files in the repo, updated by lots of different people)
Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools (e.g. tutor can ask anyone to share screen, they demonstrate the system running on their computer)
Evidence that the members of the team are working across multiple places in the code base
Short release cycles
column3: Since it was a short span project we did a lot of commits. We also did a release based on it https://github.com/ojas1901/spendwise/releases

column1: Sustainability Questions
Does your website and documentation provide a clear, high-level overview of your software?
column3: Yes there is high level overview on the readme page (https://github.com/ojas1901/spendwise/blob/main/README.md)

column1: Does your website and documentation clearly describe the type of user who should use your software?
column3: The software is a bot to be used by anyone. The readme page mentions it https://github.com/ojas1901/spendwise/blob/main/README.md

column1: Question 1.3: Do you publish case studies to show how your software has been used by yourself and others?
column3: Sample use cases in readme file (https://github.com/ojas1901/spendwise/blob/main/README.md)

column1: Question 2.1: Is the name of your project/software unique?*
Question 2.2: Is your project/software name free from trademark violations?*
column3: The name spendwise is not trademark violated

column1: Question 3.1: Is your software available as a package that can be deployed without building it?
column3: Yes we created a release where the software can be downloaded in a zip file (here)

column1: Question 3.2: Is your software available for free?*
Question 3.3: Is your source code publicly available to download, either as a downloadable bundle or via access to a source code repository?

Question 3.4: Is your software hosted in an established, third-party repository likeGitHub (https://github.com), BitBucket (https://bitbucket.org),LaunchPad (https://launchpad.net) orSourceForge (https://sourceforge.net)?
Question 4.1: Is your documentation clearly available on your website or within your software?
column3:
Yes it is available on github readme
https://github.com/ojas1901/spendwise/blob/main/README.md

column1: Question 4.2: Does your documentation include a "quick start" guide, that provides a short overview of how to use your software with some basic examples of use?
column3:
Yes we have quick start guide on readme file
https://github.com/ojas1901/spendwise/blob/main/README.md

column1: Question 4.3: If you provide more extensive documentation, does this provide clear, step-by-step instructions on how to deploy and use your software?
Question 4.4: Do you provide a comprehensive guide to all your software’s commands, functions and options?
Question 4.5: Do you provide troubleshooting information that describes the symptoms and step-by-step solutions for problems and error messages?
column3: No troubleshooting but users can raise issues

column1: Question 4.6: If your software can be used as a library, package or service by other software, do you provide comprehensive API documentation?
Question 4.7: Do you store your documentation under revision control with your source code?
column3: Yes source code is on Github

column1: Question 4.8: Do you publish your release history e.g. release data, version numbers, key features of each release etc. on your web site or in your documentation?
Question 5.1: Does your software describe how a user can get help with using your software?
column3: The users can raise issues in github or contact us on email for assistance

column1: Question 5.2: Does your website and documentation describe what support, if any, you provide to users and developers?
Question 5.3: Does your project have an e-mail address or forum that is solely for supporting users?
Question 5.4: Are e-mails to your support e-mail address received by more than one person?
Question 5.5: Does your project have a ticketing system to manage bug reports and feature requests?
column3:
Issues tab in github
Links for new feature requests and bug reports given in readme file
https://github.com/ojas1901/spendwise/issues/new/choose

column1: Question 5.6: Is your project's ticketing system publicly visible to your users, so they can view bug reports and feature requests?
Question 6.1: Is your software’s architecture and design modular?
column3: The project strucuture is good and easy to understand

column1: Question 6.2: Does your software use an accepted coding standard or convention?
column3: We use pylint to enforce coding standards

column1:
Question 7.1: Does your software allow data to be imported and exported using open data formats? *
e.g. GIF, SVG, HTML, XML, tar, zip, CSV, JSON, NetCDF, or domain specific ones
column3: We allow users to export and import data using csv format

column1:
Question 7.2: Does your software allow communications using open communications protocols? *
e.g. HTTP, FTP, XMPP, SOAP over HTTP, or domain-specific ones
column3: The software itself cannot be queried directly unless used by a telegram messanger app

column1:
Question 8.1: Is your software cross-platform compatible? *
e.g. does it run under two or more of Windows, Unix/Linux and Mac OS X, or can be used from within two or more of Internet Explorer, Chrome, Firefox and Safari?
column3: Yes since Telegram is cross platform software is cross platform

column1: Question 9.1: Does your software adhere to appropriate accessibility conventions or standards?
Question 9.2: Does your documentation adhere to appropriate accessibility conventions or standards?
Question 10.1: Is your source code stored in a repository under revision control?
Question 10.2: Is each source code release a snapshot of the repository?
Question 10.3: Are releases tagged in the repository?
Question 10.4: Is there a branch of the repository that is always stable? (i.e. tests always pass, code always builds successfully) *
column3: There is a main branch which is always stable.

column1: Question 10.5: Do you back-up your repository?
Question 11.1: Do you provide publicly-available instructions for building your software from the source code?
column3: Yes software building guide is on https://github.com/ojas1901/spendwise#rocket-installation-guide

column1:
Question 11.2: Can you build, or package, your software using an automated tool? *
e.g. Make (https://www.gnu.org/software/make/), ANT (http://ant.apache.org/), Maven (https://maven.apache.org/), CMake (https://cmake.org/), Python setuptools (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/setuptools), or R package tools (https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-exts.html)
column3: Yes, it is a python application and could be built into a python wheel package.

column1: Question 11.3: Do you provide publicly-available instructions for deploying your software?
Question 11.4: Does your documentation list all third-party dependencies?
Question 11.5: Does your documentation list the version number for all third-party dependencies?
column3: The requirements file lists all the version numbers

column1: Question 11.6: Does your sotware list the web address, and licences for all third-party dependencies and say whether the dependencies are mandatory or optional?

Question 11.7: Can you download dependencies using a dependency management tool or package manager? *
e.g. Ivy (http://ant.apache.org/ivy/), Maven (https://maven.apache.org/), Python pip (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pip) or setuptools (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/setuptools), PHP Composer (https://getcomposer.org/), Ruby gems (https://rubygems.org), or R PackRat (https://rstudio.github.io/packrat/)
Question 11.8: Do you have tests that can be run after your software has been built or deployed to show whether the build or deployment has been successful?
column3: There are tests written which runs on push or creation of PR.

column1: Question 12.1: Do you have an automated test suite for your software?
Question 12.2: Do you have a framework to periodically (e.g. nightly) run your tests on the latest version of the source code?
column3: No periodical schedule to travis.yml but it runs on push or creation of PR

column1: Question 12.3: Do you use continuous integration, automatically running tests whenever changes are made to your source code?
Question 12.4: Are your test results publicly visible?
Question 12.5: Are all manually-run tests documented?

e.g. release announcements, publications, workshops, conference presentations

column3:
Yes
Photos of all contributors are shown in readme

Question 16.1: Does your website or documentation include a project roadmap (a list of project and development milestones for the next 3, 6 and 12 months)?
column3: We do not have roadmaps as such.
